breaking_news.title: AI-Driven Attack Compromises 600+ FortiGate Firewalls Globally
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A Russian-speaking cybercriminal leveraged commercial generative AI tools to compromise over 600 internet-exposed FortiGate firewalls across 55 countries between January 11 and February 18, 2026. According to Amazon Threat Intelligence, the attacker did not exploit any FortiGate vulnerabilities; instead, they abused exposed management ports and weak single-factor credentials, using AI to automate credential stuffing, reconnaissance, and lateral movement.

Paragraph 2: This campaign marks a significant escalation in AI-augmented cybercrime, demonstrating how off-the-shelf AI services can dramatically scale infrastructure compromise without requiring zero-day exploits. The widespread nature of the breach—spanning critical infrastructure, enterprises, and service providers—heightens risks of secondary attacks, data exfiltration, and firewall reconfiguration for persistent access.

breaking_news.title: BeyondTrust RCE Vulnerability Actively Exploited in Ransomware Attacks
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Threat actors are actively exploiting CVE-2026-1731, a critical unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability (CVSS 9.9) in BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products. CISA and multiple vendors confirmed attackers are using the flaw to deploy VShell, establish persistence, move laterally, and facilitate ransomware deployment—including deploying web shells and backdoors to maintain long-term access.

Paragraph 2: The vulnerability, patched on February 6, 2026, remains unpatched across many enterprise environments, making it a high-priority target for ransomware groups. Its exploitation in active ransomware campaigns significantly increases risk for organizations relying on BeyondTrust for privileged access management, especially in healthcare, finance, and government sectors.
threat_actors: Ransomware groups (unspecified, but linked to active campaigns)

breaking_news.title: MuddyWater APT Targets MENA Orgs with New Malware Families
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The Iranian APT group MuddyWater (aka Earth Vetala, Mango Sandstorm) launched Operation Olalampo, targeting organizations in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region since January 26, 2026. The campaign deploys novel malware families including GhostFetch, CHAR, and HTTP_VIP—used for credential harvesting, command-and-control tunneling, and persistence—via spearphishing and compromised websites.

Paragraph 2: This activity reflects MuddyWater’s evolving tradecraft and strategic focus on intelligence gathering from government, telecom, energy, and media sectors. The use of newly developed, less-detectable malware underscores the group’s growing sophistication and the persistent threat posed by nation-state actors targeting critical regional infrastructure.
affected_entities: MENA-based government agencies, telecom providers, energy firms
threat_actors: MuddyWater (aka Earth Vetala, Mango Sandstorm, MUDDYCOAST)

breaking_news.title: Fake Huorong Security Site Delivers ValleyRAT to Chinese Users
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The Silver Fox APT group deployed a typosquatting campaign using the fake domain huoronga[.]com to impersonate the legitimate Huorong Security (火绒) antivirus platform. Users downloading the malicious NSIS installer received ValleyRAT—a sophisticated RAT built on the Winos4.0 framework—equipped with advanced stealth and injection capabilities to steal credentials, Wi-Fi keys, and maintain persistence.

Paragraph 2: This supply chain impersonation attack specifically targets security-conscious users in mainland China, exploiting trust in a widely used domestic antivirus product. The campaign highlights how APTs increasingly abuse software reputation and localization to bypass user skepticism and evade detection, posing serious risks to individual and enterprise systems across Asia.
affected_entities: Huorong Security (unintentionally impersonated), Chinese enterprises and individuals

breaking_news.title: CISA Adds RoundCube Flaws to KEV Catalog Amid Active Exploitation
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: CISA added two RoundCube Webmail vulnerabilities—CVE-2025-49113 (CVSS 9.9) and CVE-2025-68461 (CVSS 7.2)—to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog after confirming active exploitation. CVE-2025-49113 is a deserialization flaw that went unnoticed for over a decade and enables remote code execution; CVE-2025-68461 is a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability exploited via SVG animate tags.

Paragraph 2: RoundCube is widely used in government and enterprise email environments, and past exploitation by APT28 and Winter Vivern confirms its high-value status. The KEV designation mandates urgent patching by U.S. federal agencies and signals elevated risk for all organizations still running unpatched versions, especially those with exposed webmail interfaces.
threat_actors: APT28, Winter Vivern (historically linked to RoundCube exploitation)

breaking_news.title: Cline CLI Supply Chain Attack Installs OpenClaw on Developer Machines
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: On February 17, 2026, a compromised npm publish token enabled an unauthorized party to inject OpenClaw—a self-hosted autonomous AI agent—into Cline CLI version 2.3.0. The malicious update silently installed OpenClaw on developer systems, leveraging the tool’s legitimate access to code repositories and build environments to exfiltrate credentials and CI/CD secrets.

Paragraph 2: This supply chain attack demonstrates how open-source AI tools can become high-impact attack vectors, especially when integrated into developer workflows. With over 4,000 unintended installs reported, the compromise poses significant risk to software integrity, intellectual property, and CI/CD pipelines across startups and enterprises relying on AI-assisted coding tools.

breaking_news.title: PromptSpy First Android Malware to Abuse Google Gemini AI
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: ESET uncovered PromptSpy, the first Android malware to abuse Google’s Gemini AI at runtime for persistence. The malware leverages Gemini to analyze on-screen content and ensure it remains pinned in the recent apps list—even after reboot—enabling covert surveillance including lockscreen data capture, screenshots, screen recording, and uninstallation resistance.

Paragraph 2: This marks a new era of AI-assisted mobile threats where malware uses generative AI not for initial infection but for adaptive, long-term persistence. Given Gemini’s integration into Android 15+ devices, PromptSpy could achieve broad reach, threatening consumer privacy and enterprise data on BYOD devices, especially in high-value sectors like finance and government.
threat_actors: Unspecified threat actor (ESET attributes to AI-malware research trend)

breaking_news.title: Starkiller Phishing Service Bypasses MFA via Real-Time Proxying
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A new phishing-as-a-service operation called Starkiller, operated by the Jinkusu group, dynamically proxies real login pages and forwards credentials and MFA codes in real time. Unlike static phishing kits, Starkiller loads the actual target site and relays interactions, making it extremely difficult to detect via URL or visual inspection—effectively bypassing MFA and browser-based protections.

Paragraph 2: This service significantly lowers the barrier for credential theft campaigns, enabling less-skilled actors to conduct highly effective attacks against major platforms. Its ability to defeat modern authentication controls elevates the threat landscape, particularly for organizations relying solely on MFA without additional behavioral or device-based verification.
affected_entities: Users of major web services (e.g., Google, Microsoft, social platforms)

breaking_news.title: Vanta Diagnostics Ransomware Attack Affects 140,000 Patients
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The Everest ransomware group claimed responsibility for a breach of Vanta Diagnostics (formerly Vikor Scientific), a U.S. healthcare diagnostic firm. The attack compromised sensitive patient data, including protected health information (PHI), and forced the company to declare a breach affecting 140,000 individuals.

Paragraph 2: This incident underscores the continued targeting of healthcare providers by ransomware groups, with direct impact on patient care and regulatory compliance (HIPAA). The Everest group’s growing activity signals heightened risk for mid-sized medical labs and diagnostic centers with limited cybersecurity maturity.

breaking_news.title: Mississippi Medical Center Shuts All Clinics After Ransomware Attack
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A ransomware attack forced the University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC) to close all ~36 clinics statewide and cancel elective procedures. The attack disrupted clinical operations, patient records access, and telehealth services, with no immediate timeline for full restoration.

Paragraph 2: This incident highlights the severe operational and safety risks ransomware poses to critical healthcare infrastructure. With UMMC serving as a regional referral center, the outage impacts vulnerable patient populations and raises concerns about delayed care, data integrity, and potential downstream effects on public health response capabilities.

unique_threat_actors: MuddyWater (aka Earth Vetala, Mango Sandstorm, MUDDYCOAST)
Unspecified threat actor (ESET attributes to AI-malware research trend)
APT28, Winter Vivern (historically linked to RoundCube exploitation)
Ransomware groups (unspecified, but linked to active campaigns)
unique_affected_entities: MENA-based government agencies, telecom providers, energy firms
Users of major web services (e.g., Google, Microsoft, social platforms)
Huorong Security (unintentionally impersonated), Chinese enterprises and individuals
